title: Barbra Streisand Calls Robert Redford 'One of the Finest Actors Ever' in Tribute After His Death
summary: Barbra Streisand has shared an emotional tribute to late Hollywood legend Robert Redford, who she famously co-starred with in the classic romantic drama "The Way We Were" (1973)
story: Barbra Streisand has shared an emotional tribute to late Hollywood legend Robert Redford, who she famously co-starred with in the classic romantic drama "The Way We Were" (1973).
Streisand, 83, posted a black-and-white image on Instagram of her and Redford, who died Sept. 16 at his Utah home at age 89. In her caption, she called him “one of the finest actors ever.”

“Every day on the set of ‘The Way We Were’ was exciting, intense and pure joy. We were such opposites: he was from the world of horses; I was allergic to them! Yet, we kept trying to find out more about each other, just like the characters in the movie,” she recalled.
Streisand went on to describe Redford as “charismatic, intelligent, intense, always interesting — and one of the finest actors ever.”

“The last time I saw him, when he came to lunch, we discussed art and decided to send each other our first drawings,” she wrote, adding, “He was one of a kind and I’m so grateful to have had the opportunity to work with him.”
In Streisand’s 2023 memoir, “My Name is Barbra,” she detailed how she persuaded Redford to take on the role of Hubbell, the star-crossed lover of her character, Katie, after he initially declined it.

Streisand wrote that she wanted Redford for the role because he was a “rare combination… an intellectual cowboy… a charismatic star who is also one of the finest actors of his generation,” according to an excerpt from the book published by Vanity Fair.

Redford turned down the role, she wrote, because he felt the character of Hubbell was “shallow and one-dimensional.“ His refusal prompted Streisand to urge director Sydney Pollack to “give him whatever he wants.”
Pollack brought in two new writers who breathed life into the Hubbell character, infusing his “golden-boy exterior” with inner depth.

“The negotiations went down to the wire,” Streisand recalled in her memoir. “I was in the middle of filming ‘Up the Sandbox’ in Africa, and one day I got a telegram from (Hollywood agent) Sue Mengers that simply said: ‘Barbra Redford!’”

“That’s when I knew he’d finally said yes… and I was so thrilled! The courtship had been tough, but Bob’s reluctance had a big influence on the script and ultimately resulted in a richer, more interesting character,” wrote Streisand.

“The Way We Were” went on to become a box-office success. It was also nominated for six Academy Awards, winning two, including one for best song for Streisand’s rendition of the theme song “The Way We Were.”
Streisand and Redford reunited publicly several times over the years, including in 2002 when Streisand presented Redford with the Honorary Academy Award for lifetime achievement.
"He's always interesting. He's always interested. He's very smart. Very private. He's self-assured but shy, and I adored working with him," Streisand said during her speech.
In 2015, she lauded Redford again when she presented him with the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s Chaplin Award.

“You never quite know what he’s really thinking, and that makes him fascinating to watch on screen,” Streisand said during the ceremony, according to Entertainment Weekly. “Bob understands the power of restraint. You’re never going to get it all, and that’s the secret, I think. That’s the mystery. That’s what makes you want to keep looking at him.”
For his part, Redford also had fond memories of working with Streisand on “The Way We Were.”

“I remember the fun we had,” he recalled when he and Streisand sat for a 2010 joint interview with Oprah Winfrey. “I remember liking her energy and her spirit; it was wonderful to play off of. I also really enjoyed kidding her. She was fun to kid.”

title: Melissa Joan Hart Reveals Her 1 Parenting Regret, and What She Does Differently Now
summary: Actress Melissa Joan Hart talks about how she is shifting her parenting strategies with her three sons.
story: When it comes to raising kids, actress Melissa Joan Hart wishes she would have done one thing sooner: leaning in to "natural consequences."

"I'm very much about natural consequences now, and I feel like I kind of missed the boat a little bit on my older kids," she tells TODAY.com. Hart, who starred as the title characters in "Sabrina the Teenage Witch" and "Clarissa Explains it All," is raising three boys with her husband, musician Mark Wilkerson: Mason, 19, Braydon, 16, and Tucker, 12.
"We saved them in a lot of cases, especially when it comes to school," she says. "And that's detrimental to their development when they don't have to problem-solve or troubleshoot."

Natural consequences as a parenting strategy means that parents let kids experience real-world accountability for their actions, rather than swooping in to solve their problems. So if your child forgets their soccer cleats, for example, you let them figure it out — and maybe they don't get to play in the game or they get in trouble with the coach — rather than "saving" them by bringing their cleats to school.

Rather than taking charge of school projects as she might have done with older sons Mason and Braydon, Hart says she tries to be less of a leader and more of a helper with Tucker's sixth grade homework.

The actress is spilling secrets as part of Pop Secret’s “Spill Everything” campaign that encourages people to share their popcorn-worthy confessions. Hart, who is the “Chief of Butter” for the campaign, lets another secret fly: She loves popcorn so much that she insisted on a year’s supply before agreeing to the role.

Popcorn may be consistent, but parenting attitudes can change, and Hart certainly seems to be shifting her view on handling situations with her sons. "I let them get away with stuff, or helped them through stuff, when they probably need to figure it out themselves,” she says.
It can be hard for parents to allow kids to experience natural consequences.

"You kind of give up on it," she acknowledges. "They're your personal baby, so of course you want to forgive them and move on and let them go to that football game. We should normalize saying, 'My kids can't sleep over because they're being grounded.'"

Like many parents, Hart struggles with finding the appropriate consequences for her kids' actions. "As they get older, they get smarter and wiser and more crafty," she says, groaning that when she turned off the wifi as a consequence, they found a way to turn it right back on without her knowledge.

Hart also stops to poke fun at herself, because as she touted the benefits of natural consequences, she was waiting at the pharmacy to pick up a prescription for her 19-year-old son that he could have retrieved himself.
"But he had work and I didn't want him to leave work, so ... " she says with a laugh.

title: 'High Potential' Recap: Everything to Remember From Season 1
summary: What happened in Season 1 of "High Potential"? Here's what to remember before watching.
story: "High Potential" isn’t your typical crime drama.
Kaitlin Olson ("It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia") plays a brilliant single mom of three whose photographic memory catapults her from a job as a cleaner to one as the LAPD's secret weapon.
In the first season, Morgan Gillroy juggled motherhood and solving cases that stumped seasoned detectives. She also uncovered secrets about one of her ex-husbands, who disappeared 15 years ago.
As fans prepare for Season 2's premiere on Sept. 16, here’s what you need to remember from last season.
What Happened to Morgan's Ex-Husband, Roman?
At the heart of the series is Morgan’s first ex-husband, Roman, who vanished 15 years ago during a late-night trip to buy diapers.

For years, Morgan feared the worst — that Roman was dead. Her eldest daughter, Ava, believed Roman had abandoned them. Over the course of Season 1, the mystery surrounding Roman’s disappearance continued to shape Morgan’s personality and Ava’s resentment.

The season finale brought a breakthrough: Detective Karadec (Daniel Sunjata) discovered Roman’s whereabouts, confirming he is alive. This sets the stage for emotional reunions and potentially explosive confrontations in Season 2, as the truth behind Roman’s long absence remains unclear.
Morgan re-married and had two children with her second husband, Ludo Radovic (Taran Killam) — though they've also split.
Ava’s Perspective on Her Dad Changed
Ava (Amirah J.) grew up without her father and, for years, assumed Roman had abandoned the family.

Her perspective began to shift after overhearing a conversation between Morgan and Selena (Judy Reyes), her mother’s boss: Roman’s car had been found shortly after his disappearance, impounded with a pack of diapers inside; a clue that he likely didn’t leave voluntarily. The revelation brought Ava to tears.

In Episode 9, Morgan asked Ava if she had taken some of Roman’s belongings while going through his things, telling her she shouldn’t have to sneak around. Ava confessed she had overheard the earlier conversation about the diapers, signaling that she no longer believed her father had abandoned them.

By the season finale, Episode 13, Ava had created photo albums and artwork for Roman, preparing to catch him up on everything he had missed if he ever returns. Her emotional preparation highlights her longing and hope for reconciliation, and the mother-daughter dynamic promises to remain central in Season 2.
A Love Triangle Brewed Between Morgan, Karadec and Tom

Season 1 teased a slow-burn romance between Morgan and Detective Adam Karadec, as well as Morgan’s growing connection with Tom (JD Pardo), a former janitor-turned-nurse. Tom becomes Morgan’s romantic interest due to their shared down-to-earth nature and witty banter, offering a contrast to Karadec’s intensity.

At the season-ending police gala, Karadec’s feelings for Morgan were clear, though she remained unaware. Awestruck by her appearance, he called her stunning before becoming flustered. During a slow dance, he expressed concern about Morgan meeting Gio, a dangerous man linked to Roman’s case, and offered to go in her place. Calling her “partner” and asking her to trust him, Karadec’s willingness to risk danger marked a turning point in their relationship, and Morgan’s acceptance showed deep trust after 15 years of grief.
Their intimate moment was cut short when Tom, attending the gala as Morgan’s date, interrupted the dance, teasing a love triangle in the making.
A New Villain Enters the Scene
Season 1 ended on a chilling note with the introduction of a new, and still unnamed, villain referred to as the "gamer" (David Giuntoli).
Unlike Morgan’s usual cases, this adversary targeted her personally, leaving cryptic messages and forcing detectives to solve elaborate puzzles.
In the finale, the gamer confronted Morgan at a grocery store, declaring, “You’re the one, Morgan. We shall play again, me and you.”
His obsession with childhood games, coded messages, and psychological manipulation sets up a serialized storyline with darker and more personal stakes for Season 2.

title: 'Dancing With the Stars' Cast 2025: Who's Competing In Season 34?
summary: “Dancing With the Stars” 2025 cast for Season 34 is made up of Robert Irwin, Alix Earle, Whitney Leavitt, Jen Affleck, Corey Feldman and more.
story: The “Dancing With the Stars” cast for Season 34 is made up of TV personalities, athletes, reality stars and more.
The full list of celebrities and their professional dance partners vying for a chance to win this season’s Len Goodman Mirrorball Trophy was announced on ABC Sept. 3.

A handful of contestants had been announced prior to the big reveal, including Robert Irwin, Alix Earle and “Secret Lives of Mormon Wives” stars Whitney Leavitt and Jen Affleck. It had also been previously revealed that backup dancer Jan Ravnik will be joining the show as a pro dancer.
Julianne Hough and Alfonso Ribeiro return as “DWTS” co-hosts, with Carrie Ann Inaba, Bruno Tonioli and Derek Hough coming back as judges.
Season 33 saw former “Bachelor” star Joey Graziadei and pro Jenna Johnson take first place, while fan-favorite rugby player and Olympian Ilona Maher and Alan Bersten came in second.

Season 34 of “DTWS” premieres on Tuesday, Sept. 16, at 8 p.m. ET on ABC and Disney+, and can be streamed the next day on Hulu. Find out more details about how to watch here, and the dances they're set to perform.
See the full “Dancing With the Stars” Season 34 cast and dance pros below.

Robert Irwin was the first celebrity to be announced for Season 34 of “DWTS.” The 21-year-old is a wildlife conservationist, known for his ties to the Australia Zoo and keeping his late father Steve Irwin’s legacy alive.
Irwin is also following in the footsteps of his sister, Bindi Irwin, who competed and won Season 21 of “DWTS” in 2015. Her partner was Derek Hough.
Alix Earle is a social media influencer, with over seven million followers on TikTok. She is known for her “Get Ready With Me” (GRWM) content and vlogging.
Whitney Leavitt is a reality star and influencer known for Hulu’s “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives” and her #MomTok videos.
Jen Affleck gained popularity for being a part of Hulu’s “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives,” and will be joining her co-star Leavitt for this season of “DWTS.”
Jan Ravnik, known for being a backup dancer on Taylor Swift’s “The Eras Tour,” was announced as a pro dancer for Season 34 on Aug. 28.
Olympic gymnast Jordan Chiles is joining the cast of Season 34 along with pro Ezra Sosa.

“I don’t know if my training for gymnastics is really going to help too much with the training of dancing,” Chiles said on ABC Sept 3. “But I definitely can say the work ethic, the part that I feel confident, is definitely there.”
Child star Corey Feldman, known for his roles in 1980s classics like “The Goonies” and “Stand By Me,” will be dancing with pro Jenna Johnson.
Lauren Jauregui, one of the members of girl group Fifth Harmony, will be putting her dancing skills to the test with pro Brandon Armstrong.
Pentatonix member Scott Hoying will be paired up with pro Rylee Arnold.
Andy Richter is pivoting from late night comedy to late night dancing on Season 34. He’ll be dancing with pro Emma Slater.
“The Parent Trap” star Elaine Hendrix will be paired up with pro Alan Bersten.
NBA All-Star Baron Davis will be swapping out his basketball shoes for dancing shoes as he competes with pro Britt Stewart.
Hilaria Baldwin, the wife of actor Alec Baldwin, will be dancing alongside Gleb Savchenko.
Dylan Efron, the younger brother of Zac Efron, has made his own name in acting and is set to put his dancing skills to the test with pro Daniella Karagach.
Fans of “Boy Meets World” will be excited to see Danielle Fishel as she dances with pro Pasha Pashkov. She detailed how she's been getting in shape for the show.

title: Who Is Jan Ravnik? About the New ‘Dancing with the Stars’ Pro Who Toured with Taylor Swift
summary: Who is Jan Ravnik, the new Dancing with the Stars pro?
story: Swifties will surely recognize the new face on “Dancing With the Stars” Season 34 as professional dancer Jan Ravnik, who went viral during the “Eras Tour,” is joining the ballroom.

Ravnik was announced as the only new pro joining the “Dancing With the Stars” crew on the show’s Instagram Aug. 28. Beside a joint post with Ravnik that showed off the choreographer’s physique, the caption read, “Welcome our NEW PRO @janravnik to the #DWTS ballroom!” The post also included a video from the Slovenian pro expressing his excitement about the new season.
“Hey, ‘Dancing with the Stars’ family. My name is Jan Ravnik and I’m a new addition for this season and I’m very excited,” he said.

A few days later, ABC revealed that Ravnik will be paired with “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives” star Jen Affleck. After the news was shared, Ravnik uploaded his solo cast photo and a snap with Affleck to Instagram and cheered in the caption, “Here we GO!!!!”
The two will dance for the first time together when the Season 34 premiere arrives on Sept. 16 at 8 p.m. ET/PT and 7 p.m. CT on ABC and Disney +.

Their Week 1 performance will be a Salsa to “NUEVAYoL” by Bad Bunny, marking the start of their journey to claiming the Len Goodman Mirrorball Trophy. The pro has been sharing funny videos of the two rehearsing for their big debut.
Before checking out the premiere, learn more about the newest member of the “Dancing With the Stars” crew, below.
He Danced Alongside Taylor Swift on ‘The Eras Tour’
Ravnik became an internet sensation after becoming one of 16 backup dancers featured on Taylor Swift’s “The Eras Tour.”

He was highlighted in multiple numbers, most notably his sensual ladder choreography during “Lavender Haze.” He later poked fun at his moves on TikTok, writing, “I’d like to announce that the ladder and I have mutually decided to part ways professionally. However, we remain on good terms. It’s currently in a quiet retirement community (a.k.a. my living room), helping me paint walls and hang shelves. We ask for privacy and understanding during this heartfelt transition.”

Ravnik also went viral for the impressive strength he showed while nailing the intricate choreography for “Fortnight.” During the number, Ravnik and Swift re-created moments from the “Fortnight” music video, with him taking on Post Malone’s role opposite the pop star.

On Sept. 5, he uploaded a funny video with Affleck of a behind-the-scenes moment when the two learned that Swift and Kelce were engaged. In a joint post, Ravnik wrote, “When Jan wants to dance but Taylor just got engaged AND has a new album coming out.”
He Has Worked With Other Major Artists, Too
Prior to and after embarking on “The Eras Tour,” Ravnik’s resume has been filled with collaborations with other iconic artists.
He appeared on the 97th Academy Awards earlier this year, according to Variety. Ravnik also performed in the 2021 television special “Mariah’s Christmas: The Magic Continues.”
He has worked with Mariah Carey, Paula Abdul, Bruno Mars, Khalid, Lewis Capaldi and Luis Fonsi, as well, according to his bio on the Joffrey Ballet School’s website.
He Was a Guest Choreographer for the 2025 Dance World Cup

In July, Ravnik traveled to Burgos, Spain, to serve as a guest choreographer for the 2025 Dance World Cup. The annual competition invites dancers aged 4 to 25 all from all over the world to impress the judges with their skills. It is “the world’s largest all-genre dance competition for children and young adults,” according to its website.
This year, Ravnik joined other guest choreographers, like Abby Lee Miller, Claudimar Neto, Radar Technique and Dane Bates, and led masterclasses for the contestants for 10 days.
He uploaded a slideshow of photos and videos from his trip to Instagram, including footage from his classes.
“Thank you @danceworldcup for having me!” he wrote in the caption.

title: Jane Fonda Shares Emotional Statement About Robert Redford's Death
summary: Jane Fonda honored her longtime friend and frequent co-star Robert Redford following the news that the legendary actor and director died Sept. 16 at age 89.“It hit me hard this morning when I read that Bob was gone.
story: Jane Fonda honored her longtime friend and frequent co-star Robert Redford following the news that the legendary actor and director died Sept. 16 at age 89.
“It hit me hard this morning when I read that Bob was gone. I can’t stop crying,” Fonda, 87, said in a statement obtained by TODAY.com.
“He meant a lot to me and was a beautiful person in every way. He stood for an America we have to keep fighting for," she added.

Redford and Fonda appeared together in the 1966 drama “The Chase.” The following year, they made movie magic in the classic 1967 rom-com “Barefoot in the Park,” playing mismatched newlyweds Paul, a buttoned-up lawyer, and Corie, his free-spirited wife.

The two teamed up to play lovers again in the 1979 Western romance “The Electric Horseman.” They reunited onscreen a final time to play aging neighbors who form a tender bond in the 2017 romantic drama “Our Souls at Night."
It was during promotional interviews for that film that Fonda revealed she had “been in love” with Redford every time they'd been on set together.
“I realize that I’ve grown up because in the three previous movies, I was always in love with him. I fell in love every time,” she said during a March 2017 appearance on “The Ellen DeGeneres Show.”
“So, if a day went by and he wouldn’t speak to me, I always took it personally,” she continued, adding, “Now, when he doesn’t talk to me, I’m just like, ‘Hey Bob, come on.’”
When Fonda appeared on TODAY in September 2017, she described reuniting onscreen with Redford like two hands slipping back into “comfortable gloves.”
“There’s something about him, besides the gorgeousness,” she said of her co-star. “He’s smart, he’s funny, we have a lot in common, we both like trees, and mountains and horses.

The same month, the two Oscar winners appeared together at the premiere of “Our Souls at Night” at the Venice Film Festival. While speaking to reporters, Fonda opened up about her decades-long attraction to Redford.

“In 'Barefoot in the Park,' I couldn’t keep my hands off of him,” she said, according to The Hollywood Reporter. “I was constantly forcing myself on him. In 'Our Souls at Night,' the dynamic of my character to his character was somewhat similar. I just love the fact that these films bookend our careers.”

“We played that young love just getting married (in 'Barefoot') and now we play old people love and old people sex,” Fonda continued, joking, “Although, in my opinion, (director Batra) Ritesh cut the sex scene too soon.”
“I live for sex scenes!” Fonda added. "He’s a great kisser. It was fun to kiss him in my 20s and then to kiss him again in my almost-80s.”

title: Colin Farrell Made This 1 Snack Daily for Margot Robbie While Filming ‘A Big Bold Beautiful Journey’
summary: Colin Farrell made one very Irish snack for Margot Robbie daily while filming their movie "A Big Bold Beautiful Journey": a crisp sandwich.
story: When you think of Hollywood A-listers’ snacking habits, bread, butter and potato chips might not be the first things that come to mind.
But for “A Big Bold Beautiful Journey” co-stars Colin Farrell and Margot Robbie, that’s what makes up snack they bonded over on the set of their romantic fantasy film.
On Sept. 16, Farrell and Robbie appeared on TODAY and introduced Craig Melvin to an across-the-pond delicacy that piles carbs on carbs.

“I understand that you, also, during the course of the filming, you would send her a gift to make up every day,” Craig said to Farrell before the actor corrected the anchor — he would “deliver” it. “What was this thing you were delivering?”
“So, she loves snack,” Farrell explained.
“Even when I’m not pregnant, I love to snack,” Robbie added.
“She’s constantly got pregnant appetite for the last 30-odd years,” Farrell joked, adding that during prep for filming, they discussed food.

“We had a rehearsal period, rehearsed for like two weeks before … a lot of that was just banter, just talking about our past, and I was talking about crisp sandwiches, which she calls ‘chippy sandwiches,’” Farrell said.
“Tayto Cheese and Onion, white bread — white cheap bread — thick butter,” Farrell continued, mentioning Ireland’s premiere crisp brand. “I brought one in for her every morning, that was my job.”
“Heaven,” Robbie noted.
Of course, Craig wanted Robbie and Farrell to “feel at home” while on the show, so he brought out three freshly made crisp sandwiches to genuine excitement.
As Farrell said the sandwiches look “very good,” he had to do one thing to complete them to his liking.
“I can tell you one thing we messed up at the start,” he said, grabbing a sandwich and then pressing all of his weight into it to flatten it, making a loud crunch.
“Margot, this is yours, of course,” Farrell told her.
“I haven’t had breakfast yet,” Robbie said, taking a bite. “This is perfect.”
“Is that Tayto?” Farrell said with surprise at the sandwich’s accuracy. It was so accurate, in fact, it drove the movie star to curse live on-air.
“I f---ing knew it!” Farrell exclaimed to shock and laughter from Robbie and Craig.

Though they may seem unusual to the unfamiliar, crisp sandwiches are a staple food in the UK and Ireland. Though the origin of the recipe is up for debate, they’re said to have been created in the 1960s. Since then, they’ve become so widespread that Nigella Lawson has shared her adoration — and her own recipe — for the snack on social media.
And in a recent viral video on TikTok, one woman’s Irish fiancé taught her the “delicacy” of a crisp sandwich at 4 a.m. after an Irish wedding.
When she notes that he doesn’t toast the bread, he gives her a horrified look and says, “Toasting a crisp sandwich is crazy.”
He then presses down on the sandwich, delivering the most satisfying crunch.
“That means you know it’s good,” he says.

title: 9 of Robert Redford’s Most Memorable Movies
summary: From "The Natural" to "The Sting," here's a look at some of Robert Redford's most memorable movies and how to watch them in the wake of his death at age 89.
story: Robert Redford died Sept. 16 at the age of 89, leaving behind a legacy as one of Hollywood’s most iconic storytellers.

The Academy Award-nominated actor (he did win an Oscar, but it was for directing “Ordinary People”) appeared in a wide range of thoughtful and entertaining films, covering a wide swath of subject matter, showcasing an ability to keep moviegoers enthralled while also making them think.
Here are some of Redford’s most notable movies:
'Barefoot in the Park' (1967)

Redford had previously appeared in the stage production of “Barefoot in the Park” and had already gained traction on the big screen when he starred in the film adaptation of the Neil Simon play, about newlyweds with different personalities who move into a five-flight walkup apartment. It marked one of multiple collaborations with Jane Fonda, who played his wife in the movie.
'Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid' (1969)
Redford played the Sundance Kid. Paul Newman was Butch Cassidy. Together, these two icons made movie history in one of the defining Westerns in cinema history. The beloved film won four Oscars.
'The Candidate' (1972)

In this Oscar-winning effort, Redford played an idealistic candidate running for Senate with no realistic shot of winning who hits the campaign trail. His idealism is put to the test as he gains steam in the polls.
'The Way We Were' (1973)

There are tearjerkers and then there’s “The Way We Were.” Redford and Barbra Streisand play a couple whose love cannot overcome their ideological and political differences. Streisand earned an Oscar nomination for her role in the movie, which marked Redford’s third collaboration with director Sydney Pollack. The movie also won a pair of Oscars for Marvin Hamlisch’s music.
'The Sting' (1973)

A winner of seven Academy Awards, including best picture, Redford and Newman teamed up again in this classic that was helmed by George Roy Hill, who also directed them in “Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid.” This time, Redford and Newman play con men working on grifting a mob boss. Redford netted his lone acting Oscar nomination for “The Sting,” while Hill won best director for the movie.
'All the President’s Men' (1976)

Watergate was still very much fresh in the country’s mind when this drama about how the scandal was covered by Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward (Redford) and Carl Bernstein (Dustin Hoffman) came out. The film, which continued a run of Academy Award-winning and -nominated movies featuring Redford, collected four Oscars.
'Ordinary People' (1980)
Redford stepped behind the camera to direct this heartbreaking drama about an upper-class family coping with the death of a son and the subsequent suicide attempt of another.
'The Natural' (1984)

Baseball movies were hardly in vogue when Redford emerged for his first film role since 1980’s “Brubaker” in this drama, about an older baseball player who gets a second chance with a sad sack major league team. The film received four Oscar nominations.
'Out of Africa' (1985)

Redford and Meryl Streep made movie magic in this drama about a plantation owner (Streep) who has a torrid romance with a hunter (Redford). The movie won seven Academy Awards, including best picture and best director for Pollack.

title: Cardi B Reveals Whether She Would Get Married Again: EXCLUSIVE
summary: Cardi B says she's open to getting married again.
story: Cardi B says she's open to love again.
The Grammy-winning rapper said she would be willing to get married again while co-hosting TODAY With Jenna & Friends on Sept. 16.
"Yeah, I would get married again," Cardi B told TODAY's Jenna Bush Hager.
"I believe in love," she added with a grin on her face. "I'm like a hopeless romantic."

Cardi B first filed for divorce from her ex-husband, Offset, in 2020, after three years of marriage. In the filing, attorneys for Cardi B wrote the marriage was “irretrievably broken” and there were “no prospects for a reconciliation.”
The pair reconciled later that year, though Cardi B filed for divorce again in 2024.
A representative for Cardi B told TODAY.com in an Aug. 1, 2024, statement that her filing was “not based on any one particular incident, it has been a long time coming and is amicable.”
Cardi B and Offset share three children together: Kulture, Wave and a third child born in 2024.
The "Bodak Yellow" singer told Jenna dating hasn't changed for her since becoming a mother.

"Because everybody knows how devoted I am as a mother, so they just know that it's like, this is what I come with," Cardi B said. "I come with a luggage, a baggage, a book bag, a purse! I come with everything."
Cardi B has most recently been linked to New England Patriots wide receiver Stefon Diggs, whom she discussed with Jenna.
"You got a new man, right?" Jenna asked, which Cardi B affirmed. "Are the sparks sparking?"
"Sparklin', honey," Cardi B replied. "Fourth of July!"
Cardi B said mutual friends set her up with Diggs, and that she did not reach out to him.
"No, you're not supposed to be reach out to a man!" she said.
When Jenna asked about what life was like with Diggs, Cardi B said it was more like an expression: The rapper then pushed her hair behind her ear and stuck out her tongue and smiled.
Cardi B added that she's now a football fan to support her man.
"I be at the screen every Sunday, every day, cursing people out. Pass the ball!" she said, mimicking what she says while watching games.
She said she hasn't been able to go to one of Diggs' games yet because she's been preparing for the release of her sophomore album, "Am I the Drama?"
"But after this whole album thing, I'm going to every single game. Every single one of them," she said.

title: EXCLUSIVE: Mark Ronson on If He Wants His Daughters to Read His Memoir, 'Night People'
summary: Producer Mark Ronson speaks with TODAY.com about his new memoir, "Night People," and whether he'd want his two daughters with wife Grace Gummer to read it.
story: Mark Ronson, the Grammy-winning producer behind hits from Miley Cyrus, Bruno Mars, Amy Winehouse and more, revisits his early days as a DJ in his new memoir, "Night People."
Part of Ronson's teenage years and his early 20s was defined by his obsession with music and DJing, as well as the partying and nightlife that came with it.
Ronson, now a father of two, tells TODAY.com he wants his children to read his book one day, even though it does show what he was really doing as a teen.

"I realize I wrote a lot about the things that I did and maybe the behavior that was not so great, that I feel like one of them is going to throw it back in my face when they're 15," Ronson says. "'Dad, you were doing all of that — you're way worse than us!' But I do. I wouldn't want anything in my life that I wasn't comfortable telling them about."
Ronson married Grace Gummer, the daughter of Meryl Streep and Don Gummer, in 2021, and the couple welcomed their first child in 2023 and their second daughter earlier this year.
"Night People: How to Be a DJ in '90s New York City" published on Sept. 16, and recounts how Ronson became part of the hip-hop DJ scene in Manhattan.

Ronson, the son of Ann Dexter-Jones and Laurence Ronson, was born in London and grew up in New York City, often intermingling with his mom and stepfather’s (Mick Jones, the guitarist of Foreigner) friends at parties they threw at their house.
One of those guests? Robin Williams, Ronson wrote in his book and also shared on TODAY on Sept. 15.

“So my earliest childhood memory, are all of the night,” he said on TODAY. “My parents, they liked to go to the club too. And one night, my mom brought Robin Williams back from the club, and I’m sure she probably said, ‘You got to come into my son’s room. He loves "Mork & Mindy," that’s his favorite show.'

“And I remember just waking up and Robin Williams is over my bed, and he was leaving,” he continued. “I was like, ‘Mr. Williams, you forgot!’ He was like, ‘Nanu, nanu.’ ... He knew what I wanted to hear, it was so sweet.”
While Ronson loved being part of the DJ scene, he quickly replies "no" to a question about whether the 1990s were the best years of his life.

"I think the past few years — having two young girls, my wife and family — this has been the best part," he tells TODAY.com. "But it was certainly the most exciting, and it was this exciting era. It was the last era of its kind in New York, and, obviously, when you're in it ... you don't realize, 'This isn't going to be here forever.'"
Ronson says he decided to revisit that time in his life due to nostalgia for the music from the time, and what his life was like.

"I love the music from that era, the '90s and early 2000s — it was a time in my life where I was so excited. You know, you're 18, 19, finding your passion and your craft," he says. "And then, to be honest, a lot of my friends in that era were passing, so I wanted to find a way to remember them and this amazing little scene that we made."

The book ends before Ronson's producing career took off in the late 2000s, producing hits like Winehouse's "Rehab" and her cover of the Zutons' "Valerie." He's since gone on to produce songs like "Perfect Illusion" by Lady Gaga, "Uptown Funk" with Bruno Mars and "Electricity" with Dua Lipa and Diplo.
Ronson says he thinks he would do another book about that era of his life, but he wants to take a break after "Night People."

"I mean, this took me so long, took so much out of me that I would need to take a little bit of space and get back to making music for a while," he says. "But I would love to, at some point, make something about the people I worked with."
Ronson says there isn't anyone he's "dying to work with," but he would work with some of the artists he's worked with in the past "in a heartbeat."

"I mean, I love all of them. I would do a song with any of those people again. You know, sometimes there's this thing where you have this moment where you capture a little magic, and then to try and go back in and you're trying to chase something that you did," Ronson says. "But, I mean, there's people like Bruno and Miley — I would go in a heartbeat."

For now, Ronson says he's working with "Barbie" director Greta Gerwig again on the music for her new Netflix film. (Netflix did not respond to a request for comment on if Ronson was referring to Gerwig's new film adaptation of C.S. Lewis' "The Chronicles of Narnia" series.)
And Ronson couldn't leave TODAY without giving a shoutout to beloved weatherman Al Roker.

"I have a memory of the '90s. I feel like I saw you out on the dance floor. Like, it probably wasn't often, but I know that there was a night I was like, 'Holy crap — that's Al Roker,'" Ronson said during his show appearance.
Al didn't deny being on the dance floor at the time. "On occasion," he replied with a cheeky grin.

title: All About Robert Redford's Wife, Sibylle Szaggars Redford
summary: Following his death at the age of 89, Robert Redford leaves behind his wife, Sibylle Szaggars Redford and two daughters.
story: Following his death at the age of 89, Robert Redford leaves behind a professional legacy in the entertainment industry and a loving family.

The actor and director passed away on Sept. 16 at his home in Utah. He is survived by his wife Sibylle Szaggars, his children Shauna Schlosser Redford and Amy Redford, and seven grandchildren, per the New York Times.
In the wake of his passing, we're sharing everything you need to know about Redford's widow, including details about their love story.
Redford and Szaggars Got Married in 2009

Redford was first married to Lola Van Wagenen between 1958 and 1985. The former couple shared four children: two sons named James and Scott Redford, and two daughters — Shauna and Amy Redford. James and Scott Redford died in 2020 and 1959, respectively.

Redford married his second wife, Szaggars in 2009. Per People, the couple tied the knot in Germany in front of a small group that included 30 family members and friends. At the time, the pastor who officiated the nuptials said the newlyweds “wanted a very intimate ceremony.”
The bride, who had been living in the U.S. for 14 years at the time of her wedding, was affiliated with the parish in Germany.
Szaggars is now 68 years old.
Szaggars is an Artist

According to her website, Szaggars has worked as a multimedia environmental artist for nearly four decades. Her professional mission is to “create art that transcends words, languages, cultures and politics.”
“Szaggars Redford creates art in order to speak to a deeper universal consciousness that’s connected to and dependent on the earth and its environments,” her website reads.
Born in Germany, Szaggars' artwork has been displayed around the world, including in Europe, Asia and the U.S.
In 2016, Szaggars was the recipient of the U.S. State Department’s Art in Embassies Program for the US Embassy in Paramaribo, Suriname.

As part of the program, she visited with the country's indigenous people and explored the rainforests. Ten of her pieces of artwork were then permanently displayed in the U.S. Embassy in Paramaribo, Suriname.
Throughout her career, Szaggars has dabbled in multiple art mediums, including painted oil sketches, large oil paintings, watercolor abstracts and photography.
Szaggars Wasn't Very Familiar with Redford's Work When They First Met

In 2014, the couple participated in a panel for YoungArts. During the discussion, Szaggars admitted that she didn't know a lot about Redford when they first crossed paths in Utah while she was skiing with friends.
"I knew of him," she said, adding that she wasn't "a film person."
Szaggars shared that when Redford invited her and her friends out to dinner, she panicked a little.
"I said, 'Oh my God, I don’t know any of his films,'" she recalled.
A friend suggested that Szaggars rent some of Redford's films to familiarize herself with his work, so she did just that and watched "15 minutes randomly" from each of them.
She said Redford didn't end up talking about his films that night, though, and she felt "rescued."
Meanwhile, the actor said he was delighted to find out that Szaggars wasn't well-versed on his career.
"That’s one of the things that attracted me to her, that she didn’t know much about me. So we started from a more even playing field," he said, adding that he didn't have to worry about "any agenda."
Redford Called His Wife a 'Very Special Person'
In a 2011 interview with AARP, Redford talked about his wife and how they shared a passion for art.
“She’s a very special person,” he said. “She’s younger than I am, and European, which I like, so that’s a whole new life."
Szaggars is the Founder of a Nonprofit

In 2013, Szaggars collaborated with composer and musician David Thor Jonsson on a staged art performance piece called "The Way of the Rain" — the inspiration for the name of a nonprofit she founded in 2015.

Per her website, the organization has the goal of "developing, producing and performing educational and artistic performances" that is "themed and designed to promote public awareness to support the protection of our Earth."
Szaggars is Passionate About the Environment
In an interview with BigLife Magazine, Szaggars explained how the environment has always inspired her art.

“From the beginning of my carrier as an artist,” Szaggars said, “nature was the force that inspired me to be an activist from within my art, warning of the impending dangers of extinction, but also pointing out through color and beauty how incredible this earth is.”

title: How the Loss of 2 of His 4 Children Shaped Robert Redford
summary: Hollywood legend Robert Redford, who died on Sept. 16, 2025, had four children and seven grandchildren. Two of his four children died before him.
story: Hollywood legend Robert Redford passed away on Sept. 16, 2025 at the age of 89,  leaving an indelible mark on the movie industry — and on his family.
Redford’s work as an actor, director, philanthropist and environmental activist added a level of vibrance and heart to the world his children and grandchildren inhabit.

Together with Lola Van Wagenen, his first wife, Redford had four children and seven grandchildren. Two of those four children passed away before him. In 2009, Redford married Sibylle Szaggars; they were still married at the time of his death.

Fatherhood was a rewarding challenge for Redford. He told People in 1998, "The hardest thing in the world is when your children have problems. There have been so many hits on our family that no one knows about, and I don’t want them to, for my family’s sake."

He continued, "I’ve made some interesting movies, and I’ve been very satisfied with the work, but if someone wrapped it all up and said to me, ‘What’s your greatest achievement?’ I’d say, ‘The children. They’re the best thing in my life.’”
Robert Redford's Children
The young couple became parents when their son Scott Anthony Redford was born on on Sept. 1, 1959. He tragically passed away less than three months later from Sudden Infant Death Syndrome.

"We were just starting our lives; I was just starting my career in New York. Of course it was traumatic, and how that plays out over time, I don’t know. We had to deal with it. You have to move on," Redford told Esquire in 2017. "But it’s pretty traumatic when it happens, particularly when you’re that young. You’re not equipped to deal with it."

Born in 1960, Shauna Redford, the daughter of Redford and historian Lola Van Wagenen, has maintained a relatively private life after her college years were marked by tragedy. She attended the University of Colorado Boulder, where her boyfriend, journalism student Sid Wells, was  murdered in his off-campus apartment in 1983. More than four decades later, the case remains unsolved. In 1984, the following year, Shauna survived a serious car accident near Salt Lake City, Utah, when her car plunged into a river; wearing a seatbelt, she sustained only minor injuries.
Shauna, a professional painter, married journalist and author Eric Schlosser in 1985.
Redford's second son was born on May 5, 1962. Redford told People in 1998 that Jamie “suffered the furies” of poor health.

According to the American Society of Transplantation, Jamie was diagnosed with Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis, a rare autoimmune disease. He received two liver transplants in 1993, but cancer was discovered in his bile duct in November 2019. He was on the waiting list for a third transplant when he passed away on October 16, 2020, at the age of 58.

Like his father, Jamie was a filmmaker and activist. He founded the James Redford Institute for Transplant Awareness, where he produced a documentary titled, “The Kindness Of Strangers,” that examined the impact organ donation makes on families. He also worked on films about dyslexia, the environment, clean energy and Native American issues.
Amy Hart Redford was born on Oct. 22, 1970. She studied theater at San Francisco State University and has appeared both in front of and behind the camera.

"As a kid I witnessed the process of my dad making films and the extraordinary cast of characters that came together to make it happen," she told IndieWire in 2008. "I found myself drawn to the nomadic and creative life that that implied."

“I am able to talk to my dad in a way a lot of people can’t," Amy told the New York Times in 2008. "He still drives me nuts, he’s still my dad, but I have to say, in light of what his universe was, he had his eye on the ball in terms of having kids, and part of that was being raised in Manhattan.”
Robert Redford's 7 Grandchildren
“The word grandfather is weird,” Redford told People in 1998. “It feels like some old guy in a robe.”
Weirder still are some of the names Redford's grandchildren once called him: "Bo-Pa" or "Ba-Poo." In all, Redford had seven grandchildren.
Shauna and her husband Eric Schlosser have two kids: Anna Michaela “Mica” Redford Schlosser (born in January 1991) and Conor James Schlosser (born on July 29, 1992)
James and his wife Kyle also have two kids: Dylan Larsen Redford (born Oct. 16, 1991) and Lena Hart Redford (born in November 1995).
Amy and her ex-husband Matt August have three kids: daughter Eden (born in 2008) and twin girls (born in 2010).
Many of Redford's grandchildren work in the film industry.

title: Silver-Screen Icon and Oscar-Winning Director Robert Redford Dies at 89
summary: Oscar-winning director and legendary actor Robert Redford, who starred in "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" and "Out of Africa," has died at age 89.
story: Robert Redford, whose dashing looks and magnetism combined with his thought-provoking and entertaining films that made him a star both on screen and as a director, has died. He was 89.

“Robert Redford passed away on September 16, 2025, at his home at Sundance in the mountains of Utah — the place he loved, surrounded by those he loved. He will be missed greatly. The family requests privacy,” Cindi Berger, the chief executive of the publicity firm Rogers & Cowan PMK, told NBC News.

Born Aug. 18, 1936, Redford found success on Broadway in the late 1950s and drew acclaim in the 1963 production of Neil Simon’s “Barefoot in the Park.” According to IMDb, his first on-screen credit was a 1960 episode of “Maverick.” He landed roles on several TV shows as the decade wore on, earning an Emmy Award nomination for outstanding performance in a supporting role for a 1962 episode of “Alcoa Premiere.”

Redford eventually transitioned into film, beginning with 1965’s “Situation Hopeless — But Not Serious,” and won a Golden Globe Award for new star of the year for his work in another 1965 film, “Inside Daisy Clover.”

He enjoyed more success in “The Chase,” “This Property Is Condemned” — which marked the first of seven collaborations with director Sydney Pollack — and the big-screen adaptation of “Barefoot in the Park” with Jane Fonda, the first of a few film collaborations with the actor, who later said she was "in love with" him.

Redford, though, made the leap to bona fide superstar in 1969’s “Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid,” in which he played Sundance and co-starred alongside Paul Newman. Considered one of the best Westerns of all time, it was the highest-grossing film of the year and was selected in 2003 for inclusion in the National Film Registry.

“The combination of (my and Newman’s) friendship, and the weirdness of that song — I think you put all that together and there was just something indelible about it,” Redford told The Salt Lake Tribune in 2019, referring to the hit song “Raindrops Keep Fallin’ on My Head” that appeared in the movie.
In 1972, he starred in “The Candidate,” kicking off a run in which he was a box office force.
Redford next appeared with Barbra Streisand in “The Way We Were,” considered by many to be one of the most romantic movies ever, focusing on a couple with different beliefs who fall in love.

Redford followed that up with “The Sting” — which netted him his lone Oscar nomination for best actor and reunited him with Newman — “The Great Gatsby,” “The Great Waldo Pepper,” “Three Days of the Condor” and “All the President’s Men.” All of those films, with the exception of “The Great Waldo Pepper,” were nominated for Oscars.

“The Sting” won seven Academy Awards, including best picture, while “All the President’s Men” teamed Redford up with Dustin Hoffman to tell the story of Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein’s uncovering of the Watergate scandal. That film won four Oscars and was nominated for four more.

Redford’s hot streak didn’t end there, though. He again co-starred with Fonda in 1979’s “The Electric Horseman.” The 1980s continued his growth as an artist and entertainer, beginning with him portraying a prison warden in 1980’s “Brubaker.”

Redford took a break from the big screen for a few years before returning in 1984’s “The Natural,” playing a mysterious middle-aged baseball player who joins a hapless team and propels them into the pennant race.

A year later, he starred in “Out of Africa,” which won seven Academy Awards. He would also star in “Havana,” “Sneakers” and “Indecent Proposal,” as a billionaire whose offer to spend the night with a married woman tests the mettle of her marriage.
Redford would also join the superhero universe, starring as Alexander Pierce in “Captain America: The Winter Soldier” and “Avengers: Endgame.”

Redford’s penchant for thoughtful films was not limited to his work as an actor, either. His first directorial effort was 1980's “Ordinary People,” about a family coping with the loss of a child. That movie won him the Oscar for best director, while the drama also won best picture and two other Academy Awards.
“I never dreamed in a million years that it would have the result that it did. I kind of thought it would be buried,” he told Entertainment Weekly in 2016.

Redford struck gold again with 1994’s “Quiz Show,” about the game show scandal of the 1950s. He earned another Oscar nomination for best director, while the movie was nominated for three other Academy Awards, including best picture.

Redford also directed “The Legend of Bagger Vance” and helped put stars on the map, helming a young Scarlett Johansson in “The Horse Whisperer” and Brad Pitt in “A River Runs Through It,” one of the movies that signaled the arrival of the young actor. Redford and Pitt would later appear on camera together in 2001’s “Spy Game.”

Redford, who told TODAY in 2015 he didn’t watch his own movies, announced his retirement from acting in 2018. He is also credited with founding the Sundance Film Festival in 1984, which is one of the first and premier independent film festivals in the world.
“It was a big idea with a small smart,” he told “Democracy Now” in 2015.
“It started as just a hope. Then, when it became a reality, it started to have its own momentum,” he added.

Redford was married twice. He was married to Lola Van Wagenen in 1958, but they later divorced. They had four children, two of whom died. In 2009, he married Sibylle Szaggars, whom he was still with at the time of his death.

title: Mariska Hargitay and Chris Meloni Carry On Cute Emmy Awards Tradition: See Photos
summary: "Law & Order" co-stars Mariska Hargitay and Chris Meloni posted adorable photos together from the 2025 Emmy Awards, including pics of Meloni carrying Hargitay.
story: Chris Meloni has Mariska Hargitay's back ... and front. Well, he has all of her.
The longtime friends who first met at a "Law & Order: SVU" audition in the late '90s had a ball, again, at the Emmy Awards Sept. 14.

The pair presented the award for outstanding drama series alongside fellow "Law & Order" franchise stars Ice-T and Tony Goldwyn, as well as former cast member S. Epatha Merkerson. The gathering of actors was also in honor of 35 years of the mothership "Law & Order" series, which began in 1990 and ran for 20 seasons before going off the air. It returned in 2022.
Hargitay and Meloni, who were also seated alongside Goldwyn and Ice-T in the audience of the award show, documented all the fun they had on social media.
Meloni shared selfies with his "L&O" seatmates in an Instagram post, and Hargitay also posted a photo of herself and Meloni with the simple caption "You're welcome."
Little did their fans know the two were just getting started.
Meloni later shared more photos and a video of himself with Hargitay.

In the first pic, they pose in front of a large Emmy statue. The real fun is in the second slide: a sly video Meloni captured of Hargitay, who has an Emmy for her role as Olivia Benson, near a table filled with Emmy statues jokingly saying, "You'll never have that." Hargitay starts cracking up once she realizes Meloni is filming, and he quips, "See what I go through? You see what I deal with." The last slide is a snuggled-up snap of the duo with Jennifer Coolidge.

Just when it seemed like the behind-the-scenes fun was done, Hargitay posted even more images from the night, sneaking in a few cute photos from the end of the evening with Meloni carrying her, bridal style.
The last four slides show Hargitay and Meloni together onstage, holding hands on a red carpet outside the venue and Meloni carrying Hargitay in his arms.
The images are reminiscent of a scene between their characters, Benson and Detective Elliot Stabler, when Benson got shot and Stabler picked her up and carried her to safety.
The pics also echo the fun they had after the Emmys in 2022, when they attended together.
At the time, Meloni posted a photo to X of himself giving Hargitay a piggyback ride.
"How it started. How it ended," he captioned the post, along with the hashtags #Eleganceissurprisinglylight, #partnerscarryingpartners and #highheelcasualty.
Fans will see Benson and Stabler together on screen soon.
A new promo for "Law & Order: SVU" shows the characters sharing a scene.
Meloni was also spotted on the "SVU" set in August and captured the moment in an adorable Instagram post.
"Hangin with friends on a Friday nite," he wrote in his caption, tagging Hargitay and OG cast member Dann Florek, whose reason for also being on set remains to be seen.

title: ‘The Summer I Turned Pretty’ Finale Is Almost Here. How to Watch
summary: "The Summer I Turned Pretty" finale airs Sept. 17. Here's how to watch the final episode in Belly's story.
story: After three years of Belly Conklin’s will-they-won’t-they dynamic with both Conrad and Jeremiah Fisher, fans will see how the conclusion to her story unfolds when “The Summer I Turned Pretty” airs its final episode.
Season 3, Episode 11, which doubles as the show’s series finale, arrives on Prime Video Wednesday, Sept. 17.

So far this season, viewers have watched Belly, played by Lola Tung, wrestle with her feelings for Jeremiah and Conrad, played by Gavin Casalegno and Christopher Briney, respectively, despite being engaged to the younger Fisher sibling. She decided not to say “I do” to Jeremiah and as of the penultimate episode, has embraced life in Paris.

Fans have pointed out that since Season 3, Episode 8, the series has been drifting into “uncharted territory,” straying from the Jenny Han books it was adapted from. Plus, a previously released teaser for the last three episodes ended with the moment Belly received a letter from Conrad in Paris, leaving many to anxiously anticipate what will happen in the last episode.
Want to make sure you don’t miss the epic send-off? Find out how to tune into “The Summer I Turned Pretty” series finale.
What Time Will ‘The Summer I Turned Pretty’ Finale Come Out?

Fans will witness the dramatic ending to Belly, Conrad, Jeremiah, Steven (Sean Kaufman) and Taylor’s (Rain Spencer) coming-of-age journey when “The Summer I Turned Pretty” series finale is released on Wednesday, Sept. 17, at midnight PT/ 3 a.m. ET.
Where to Watch ‘The Summer I Turned Pretty’ Finale
“The Summer I Turned” Pretty Season 3 finale will stream exclusively on Prime Video. All 11 episodes, as well as Seasons 1 and 2, will be available to watch on the platform, too.
Will There Be a Season 4 of ‘The Summer I Turned Pretty’?
Although “The Summer I Turned Pretty” fans would surely welcome another season, it appears that Season 3, Episode 11, will truly be the end to the series.

The teen drama is based on Jenny Han’s bestselling young adult series, which consists of three novels. The show is following a similar format and will wrap after three seasons. Prime Video has also consistently referred to Season 3 as the final season in press releases about the show.
However, Han has expressed interest in continuing Belly’s story.
“Never say never — I never do,” she said in a June interview with Entertainment Weekly about possible future seasons.
Han added, “If I had a really great idea that I was excited by, and if (the stars) were excited to do it, then I would be so pumped.”

title: Kaitlyn Dever Honored Her Late Mom With Her 2025 Emmys Look
summary: Kaitlyn Dever's 2025 Emmys look was a tribute to her late mom, who died last year. The "Last of Us" actor shared the story behind her gold jacket.
story: There's a touching story behind Kaitlyn Dever's 2025 Emmys look.
The “Last of Us” star arrived at the awards ceremony in Los Angeles on Sept. 14 in a custom Michael Kors design, which included a special nod to her late mother.
Dever’s mom, Kathy, died in 2024 due to complications from breast cancer.
“This is my mom’s jacket,” she told “Entertainment Tonight” on the red carpet, explaining how a couple years ago her mom bought the vintage piece in hopes of wearing it on a special day.
“She was like, ‘When you get nominated for an Emmy, I want to wear this with you,’” Dever shared. “And unfortunately, she’s no longer with us tonight to wear it.”
“But I had to wear it in her honor,” she continued.

Dever was nominated for outstanding guest actress in a drama series for her role as Abby in the HBO series. The category was announced during the Creative Arts Emmys, held a weekend prior to the televised Emmy Awards.

The day after the Emmys, she shared photos from the carpet and when she got ready on her Instagram. In the caption, she thanked the designer for the bespoke look, calling the outfit “the most beautiful more special, custom, look I’ve ever ever had.”

“This is my mamas jacket :) I’m so glad I got to have her with me last night and I’m so grateful for the team at Micheal Kors for putting all together,” she wrote, thanking her sister Jane “for styling.” “I’m so happy I got to honor my mama ….and of course a lil heartbreaker, which ALWAYS makes me think of her.”
Dever attended the Emmys to support her fellow cast members, including Pedro Pascal and Bella Ramsey, who were nominated that night.
“It’s just fun to be supporting ‘The Last of Us,’” she said, before touching on leading the next season of the show. “I’m processing it. It’s a big deal!”

Dever joined the hit show for its second season. Earlier this year, she shared how she had to film a devastating scene that involved the death of a major character just weeks after the death of her mom.

“To be as honest as possible, I will just say that my days leading up to this scene were horrible,” she told Entertainment Weekly in April. “I lost my mom two or three weeks before I actually shot this scene and my mom’s funeral was three days before I did my first day. So I was sort of in a fog. I was in a daze.”
Dever announced the death of her mom in February 2024, sharing a slideshow filled with photos of the two, and their family, over the years.

“My mama. My life. My everything. I don’t even have the words,” she wrote in part. “Nothing I’ll ever say will amount to the gifts you have given me in my life, the boundless joy you brought, the deep, endless, unconditional love you gave me and our family. Your love was everywhere.”

title: Trump will be feted by Britain's royal family as Europe seeks help in ending Ukraine's war
summary:
U.S. President Donald Trump flew to London where King Charles III will fete him and 
British Prime Minister Keir Starmer will press for help ending the Ukraine war.
story: LONDON — President Donald Trump touched down Tuesday in a country whose king is prepared to fete him, and whose citizenry roundly dislikes him.

Happily for the president, he will see a lot of King Charles III and little of everyday Britons in a two-day trip where he’ll make history as the first elected leader to receive not one but two state visits courtesy of the royal family.

Looming over Trump’s arrival in Europe is the war playing out on the east end of the continent. Hostilities between Russia and Ukraine took an escalatory turn last week when Russian drones entered Poland’s airspace and were shot down.

The incident renewed fears that Russian President Vladimir Putin may widen the conflict and threaten other European democracies unless he is stopped. As the war grinds on, Trump’s effort to make peace has stalled, giving rise to complaints among some diplomats and members of Congress that he is not putting enough pressure on Putin to halt the attacks.

The war figures to come up when Trump meets privately on Thursday with British Prime Minister Keir Starmer at Chequers, his official country residence outside London. There, the two leaders will view the archives of former Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

The symbolism is unmistakable. Churchill and President Franklin D. Roosevelt forged an invaluable friendship as they joined to fight Nazi Germany in World War II. Russia was part of the troika that defeated Adolf Hitler.
Now, the West faces threats from a Russian dictatorial regime, and Europe again is beseeching the U.S. president to come to its aid.

Whether Trump is on board seems to depend on the day. He has sent mixed signals about responsibility for the war, which began in 2022 when Russia sent tanks and troops rolling into Ukraine. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy rallied his country and prevented a quick rout. In a post on his social media site Saturday, Trump wrote that the war is not his. Rather, he wrote, “it is [former President Joe] Biden’s and Zelenskyy’s war.” He did not mention Putin.
But speaking to reporters the following day, he cast Russia as the “aggressor.”
Trump said over the weekend that he is prepared to slap "major" sanctions on Russia, but first wants all 32 nations in the NATO military alliance to stop buying Russian oil.

“I hope that the leaders who meet Trump these days behind closed doors are very frank about it,” Marko Mihkelson, who chairs the foreign affairs committee in Estonia’s Parliament, said in an interview. “If Mr. Trump thinks that this is not his war or that he can run away and that Ukraine is somehow a faraway country, that would be an epic mistake.”

First, though, comes the pomp. World leaders have long used flattery in attempting to win favor with Trump. In this instance, Starmer hand-delivered an invitation from King Charles during a meeting in the Oval Office in February. Trump’s last state visit, in 2019, was a “tremendous success,” gushed Starmer, who is relying on Trump to stand up for Ukraine and prevent further Russian aggression.

“Every time the European Union tries to push against Trump, they’ve gone to incredible efforts to butter him up," said Michael Bociurkiw, a senior fellow at the Atlantic Council think tank. He mentioned that Mark Rutte, secretary-general of the NATO military alliance, called Trump "Daddy” at a summit in June and how European leaders praised Trump during a visit to the White House in August to discuss the war, likening them to a “cheerleading squad meeting with the football coach.”
The upcoming state dinner "is another iteration of what has become the strategy for dealing with Trump," said Michael McFaul, who was ambassador to Russia during the Obama administration.
"I'm not surprised that they [the British] are going to do it, and because of our cultural and historical connections, they can do it like virtually no other country in the world," he continued.

A group called the “Stop Trump Coalition” is staging a protest during the president's visit, but he isn’t likely to see it. He’ll be an overnight guest of the king and Queen Camilla at Windsor Castle on Wednesday and will join the royal couple for a carriage procession inside the private estate. By contrast, when French President Emmanuel Macron visited earlier this year, his carriage ride took him through the town of Windsor.

title: Ukrainian children have been taken to more than 200 facilities in Russia, new report finds
summary: Ukrainian children have been taken to over 200 different facilities across Russia, where they have been subjected to forced “re-education” and military training.
story: Ukrainian children have been taken to over 200 different facilities across Russia, including locations where they have been subjected to forced “re-education” and military training in a clear violation of international law, according to new research.

Eight different types of facilities, ranging from summer camps to religious sites to military academies stretching across the entire expanse of Russia, have been identified in the report from the Yale School of Public Health Humanitarian Research Lab published Tuesday.

The study was initiated at Ukraine’s request to better understand the full size of the network of facilities where children are held, to help them eventually return to their homeland, Nathaniel Raymond, the executive director of the research lab, said in a telephone interview Sunday.
“It’s really important that all the people involved in different ways to bring the kids back have the most accurate geospatial information possible, and this is it,” he said.

Using open-source intelligence, news reports and Russian government documents, as well as satellite imagery, the Yale report identified 210 different locations where children are taken. Some are brought to locations temporarily, while others are given Russian citizenship and coerced into forced adoption, the report says.
At most sites, children go through “re-education” programs to enforce Russian patriotism, including lectures in Russian history and singing the national anthem, it adds.

Others, particularly older children, have received military training at cadet academies and a military base, including “drone control and tactics training,” and have participated in shooting and grenade-throwing competitions, according to the report.
The researchers said they cannot verify if any of the children given military training were ever conscripted into the Russian military or were otherwise deployed in the war in Ukraine.
Russia’s children’s rights commissioner, Maria Alekseyevna Lvova-Belova, and the country’s foreign ministry did not respond to requests for comment.

Ukraine’s official “Bring Kids Back” program, which partners the government with other countries and international organizations to return kids from Russia, has recorded nearly 20,000 cases of unlawful deportations and forced transfers of children.

The new report does not estimate the number of children who have been held either temporarily or indefinitely in Russia. But Raymond said identifying the locations gives a better sense of the scale, comparing it to the carnival game of trying to guess the number of jelly beans in a jar.
“Right now, with this report, we volumetrically know as much as we’re probably going to know how big the jar is, and the jar is gigantic,” he said.

The report builds on research that has helped support allegations of war crimes against Russian President Vladimir Putin issued by the International Criminal Court, which has issued an arrest warrant accusing him of overseeing the forced abductions and deportations. The ICC has also accused Lvova-Belova of committing similar crimes.
The Kremlin has previously denied the allegations and said the warrants were “outrageous.”

Ukraine has made the return of abducted children central to any talks with Russia to end the war. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy raised the issue with President Donald Trump during a meeting at the White House last month, days after Trump’s meeting with Putin in Alaska.
Last week, Zelenskyy announced plans to hold a “high-level event” on abducted children during the meeting of the U.N. General Assembly later this month.

The research was hampered after State Department funding for the Conflict Observatory program, which Yale was part of, was cut by executive order by Trump. It has not been restored. All of the data would have been lost, but a contractor working on the project in Florida protectively kept a backup, according to Raymond.
The lab’s repository of data has been transferred to Europol, a European law enforcement agency.
The researchers have also stopped directly sharing their findings with the ICC after the Trump administration-imposed sanctions on the court in February.

Previously, Raymond said, the lab had cooperated with the ICC on investigations of allegations of war crimes committed in Ukraine on the basis of an agreement put in place during the Biden administration.

Now, he said, researchers are operating under the assumption that the previous agreement is no longer valid. “We no longer believe that it is safe for us to attempt to share information with them, given the lack of clarity legally from the Trump administration,” he said.

However, a new bipartisan push in the Senate is underway to label Russia a state sponsor of terrorism unless it returns Ukrainian children taken during the war. Sens. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C.; Richard Blumenthal, D-Conn.; Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn.; and Katie Britt, R-Ala., introduced a bill last week threatening to add both Russia and Belarus to the list, which currently includes only Cuba, Iran, North Korea and Syria.

title: How Gen Z-led protests are rattling governments across Asia
summary: Even though they happened 2,000 miles apart, deadly anti-government protests in Nepal and Indonesia have a common denominator: They are being led by Gen Z, those born between 1997 and 2012
story: Even though they happened 2,000 miles apart, deadly anti-government protests in Nepal and Indonesia have a common denominator: They are being led by Gen Z, those born between 1997 and 2012.

Though people under 30 make up about half the population in both Asian democracies, the immediate reasons for their outrage were different. In Nepal, demonstrations were set off by a social media ban, while in Indonesia anger erupted over lavish perks for government officials.
But they share the driving force of young people who are furious over a lack of jobs, rampant corruption and rising economic inequality.

“Young people are being forced into precarious types of employment, including young people with education,” said Vedi Hadiz, a professor of Asian studies at the University of Melbourne’s Asia Institute. “Young people are angry and feel unprotected or feel that their futures are not secure.”

title: Scientists say they've found the world's oldest mummies, and they're far from Egypt
summary: Mummies are most often associated with Egypt, where the oldest ones are about 4,500 years old. But researchers say they have found mummies that are much older, on the other side of the world.
story: Mummies are most often associated with Egypt, where the oldest ones are about 4,500 years old. But researchers say they have found mummies that are much older on the other side of the world.

“We found that in southern China and Southeast Asia, there were many archeological sites that contain human burials that are between four and 14,000 years old,” Professor Peter Bellwood, a co-author of the study, said in a phone interview on Tuesday.

The study, which was published Monday in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, examined 54 pre-Neolithic burials from 11 archaeological sites in southern China and Southeast Asia, with large numbers of samples coming from Vietnam and China’s Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region and smaller numbers coming from the Philippines, Laos, Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia.

Human remains were found in tightly crouched or squatting postures, often with traces of burning. The researchers said findings confirmed that many of the remains had been smoke-dried over fire for extended periods before burial in a process of mummification.

The remains “belong to an original hunter-gatherer population that occupied Southeast Asia in Paleolithic times, and that continued in occupation in places like Australia and New Guinea through into current times,” said Bellwood, an emeritus professor of archaeology at the Australian National University in Canberra.
Previously, the oldest known mummies had been found not in Egypt but in modern-day Peru and Chile, where they were prepared by a fishing people called the Chinchorro about 7,000 years ago.
The findings also impressed a leading expert on ancient Egypt.

“The term has been taken on by other groups to identify other preserved bodies. So it’s got a much more general understanding now,” Salima Ikram, a professor of Egyptology at the American University in Cairo who was not involved in the research, said in an interview.
“What is nice is that the idea behind it is similar, because they wanted to preserve the body,” she added.
The project began in 2017 with a casual conversation between two of its lead authors and later expanded to include 24 experts.

“We have gradually gathered multiple lines of evidence over many years,” Hsiao-chun Hung, a lead author of the study, said in an email. “It’s a bit like detective work — finding small clues, piecing them together, and growing increasingly confident in the hypothesis.”

title: Why the U.K. is arresting peaceful pro-Palestinian protesters on terrorism charges
summary: LONDON — Richard Whitmore-Jones had never protested before reaching his 70s, but British police have arrested him three times this summer for holding a cardboard sign, leaving the retired executive facing three sets of terrorism charges
story: LONDON — Richard Whitmore-Jones had never protested before reaching his 70s, but British police have arrested him three times this summer for holding a cardboard sign, leaving the retired executive facing three sets of terrorism charges.
Each time, the 74-year-old said he had been sitting silently outside the British Parliament holding a placard that read: “I oppose genocide. I support Palestine Action.”
“We’re not talking to anybody, we’re not being interviewed, we’re simply sitting there with a sign,” Whitmore-Jones, who faces a court date in October, told NBC News.
Four words written on the sign triggered Whitmore-Jones' arrest: I support Palestine Action.
Alongside Al Qaeda and ISIS

The British government banned Palestine Action — which describes itself as a direct action movement that uses disruptive methods — as a terrorist organization in July, putting it alongside Al Qaeda and the Islamic State terrorist group, or ISIS. It made membership in or support of the group a criminal offense punishable by up to 14 years in prison under British law.
This extends to acts such as wearing clothing, carrying items or holding placards in public that could reasonably be seen as showing affiliation with the group.
Nearly 900 people were arrested at protests in central London on Saturday alone, many older than 60.

title: Spain to quit 2026 Eurovision Song Contest if Israel participates
summary: Spain became the latest country to threaten to boycott Israel’s continued participation of the Eurovision Song Contest.
story: Momentum is building to exclude Israel from the world’s largest music competition as outrage grows around the world about its assault on the Gaza Strip.

Spain, on Tuesday, became the latest country to threaten to boycott Israel’s continued participation of the Eurovision Song Contest, the glitzy singing competition that is watched by some 160 million people around the world every May.
In a statement, Spanish broadcaster RTVE said its board had voted to withdraw from the 2026 competition if Israel participates.
It came after Irish broadcaster RTÉ and Dutch broadcaster AVROTROS also issued statements earlier this month, saying they would not take part if Israel was allowed to compete.
Spanish politicians have been among the most vocal critics of Israel in recent months and have made no secret of their preference for Israel not to take part in Eurovision.

“Spain must do everything possible to ensure that Israel is not included in Eurovision. And if Europe fails to rise to the occasion, our country must act accordingly,” Spanish Culture Minister Ernest Urtasun said in a post on Bluesky on Sunday.

Israel called out Spain's decision, with Minister of Culture and Sports Miki Zohar calling it a "disgraceful and hypocritical" step that contradicted the values of Eurovision and "the spirit of unity at its core."
“Eurovision is a celebration of music, culture, and fraternity among nations — not a stage for political point-scoring," he said.

Speaking a day after pro-Palestinian protesters disrupted the Vuelta a España bicycle race over the participation of an Israeli team Monday, Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez said Israel should not take part in international competitions. “Our position is clear and unequivocal: until the barbarity ceases, neither Russia nor Israel should participate in any international competition,” he said.
Protesters also disrupted the race on Wednesday, prompting some riders to threaten to quit.

Israeli Foreign Minister Gideon Saar responded to Sanchez's comments by calling him “an antisemite and a liar” in a message on X on Monday. The Spanish Foreign Ministry said it would summon the Israeli charge d’affaires Tuesday to protest.
The Eurovision boycott threats come as Israel faces increasing isolation in the cultural sector over its actions in Gaza.

Organizers of the Flanders Festival Ghent in Belgium called off a concert by Germany’s famed Munich Philharmonic citing a lack of “clarity” over the views of its incoming Israeli conductor, Lahav Shani.
Shani, who is the music director of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, is due to become the German orchestra's  chief conductor next year.

But ahead of the performance in the Belgian city of Ghent, festival organizers said they were unable to determine Shani's current “attitude to the genocidal regime in Tel Aviv,” although he has previously spoken in favor of peace and reconciliation.
Israel vehemently denies that it is committing genocide in Gaza.

But at a recent qualifier match between Israel and Italy for next year's soccer world cup, Italian fans could be seen turning their backs as Israel’s national anthem played before the game which was played in Hungary due to the ongoing security situation.
Israel first took part in Eurovision in 1973, and while there have been small protests against its participation for years, they have increased significantly since the country’s war in Gaza began.

The conflict, sparked by the Hamas-led terrorist attacks on Israel that killed some 1,200 people and saw hundreds taken hostage in Gaza, has prompted international condemnation as the death toll in the enclave has passed 64,000, according to Palestinian health officials.

The two contests that have taken place since the start of the war have seen calls for a boycott, street protests and boos in the arena during the Israeli entrant’s performance.
